title: R41931
content: The federal mail and wire fraud statutes are powerful tools for prosecutors, but they have also faced criticism for their broad application and potential impact on business negotiations and due process. Despite concerns, these statutes have been effective in ending schemes that defraud victims of millions, and sometimes billions, of dollars. Both the mail and wire fraud statutes aim to prevent fraudulent conduct using mail or wire communications, punishable by up to 20 years in prison or 30 years if the victim is a financial institution. They allow for restitution, property forfeiture, and are often interpreted interchangeably by the courts. The mail and wire fraud statutes require the government to prove the use of mail or wire communications in furtherance of a scheme to defraud, involving material deception and intent to defraud another of property or honest services. The statutes apply to anyone who transmits communications for the purpose of executing a fraudulent scheme. The statutes for mail and wire fraud require communications to be in furtherance of a fraudulent scheme. The communication does not need to be essential but must be part of the scheme's execution as intended by the perpetrator. It can include communications to deceive, delay inquiries, or make transactions less suspicious. Personal involvement in mailing or wiring is not necessary for liability. The mail and wire fraud statutes prohibit any scheme to defraud or obtain money by false pretenses, representations, or promises. Congress intended to reach a wide range of fraudulent schemes and has expanded the concept over time. Personal involvement in mailing or wiring is not necessary for liability. The mail and wire fraud statutes prohibit schemes to defraud or obtain money by false pretenses. Congress has expanded the concept over time, including schemes to defraud another of honest services. The crime is committed when the scheme is hatched, regardless of its success. Demonstrating a scheme to defraud requires showing communications were intended to deceive. The mail and wire fraud statutes cover schemes designed to deceive victims, including those who are gullible. The focus is on the defendant's intent and the materiality of the deception. The statutes prohibit schemes to defraud or obtain money by false pretenses, with the Supreme Court clarifying that "to defraud" and "to obtain money or property" describe the same crime. The mail and wire fraud statutes protect against schemes to defraud by obtaining money or property through false pretenses. The statutes cover tangible and certain intangible property rights that have value to the victim. Courts determine if an interest is considered property based on traditional recognition and enforcement as a property right. The mail and wire fraud statutes require a material misrepresentation to constitute a scheme to defraud. Materiality is essential for proving intent to deceive and causing harm. Misrepresentation is considered material if it can influence the victim. The mail and wire fraud statutes require material misrepresentation for a scheme to defraud. A defendant has a complete defense if they believe deceptive statements to be true or act without intent to defraud. The Supreme Court ruled in McNally v. United States that the statutes did not protect the intangible right to good government. Congress later expanded the protection to include honest services. The Supreme Court limited the definition of honest services fraud to cases of bribery or kickbacks in Skilling v. United States. Bribery requires a quid pro quo, while an official act involves a formal exercise of governmental power. The definition of kickback has been redefined since the Skilling case. The definition of honest services fraud was limited by the Supreme Court in Skilling v. United States to cases involving bribery or kickbacks. The courts have cited dictionary definitions for kickbacks, and honest services fraud is closely related to mail and wire fraud statutes. Conspiracy to commit wire fraud requires an agreement between two or more persons and willful participation by the defendant. Conspiracy to commit wire fraud involves an agreement between two or more persons, with the defendant willfully joining the conspiracy. A conspirator is liable for offenses committed by co-conspirators in furtherance of the conspiracy. Attempt to commit mail and wire fraud requires a substantial step towards the offense with intent, and does not need to be successful. Conviction for both the substantive offense and attempt is not allowed. Mail and wire fraud carry a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a fine. Mail and wire fraud can result in imprisonment for up to 20 years and a fine of up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). If the victim is a financial institution or the offense is related to a natural disaster, the penalty can be up to $1 million and 30 years in prison. Using identity theft during the fraud can lead to a mandatory minimum two-year prison term. Other consequences may include probation, supervised release, special assessments, restitution orders, and forfeiture orders. Supervised release is recommended in all felony cases. The Sentencing Guidelines recommend supervised release in all felony cases, with a maximum term of three years for wire and mail fraud, or five years if the fraud is against a financial institution with a 30-year maximum term of imprisonment. Violation of release conditions may result in up to two years in prison. Mandatory conditions include no new crimes, DNA sample, and drug testing. Additional standard conditions may be imposed by the court. Restitution and forfeiture are standard conditions for defendants convicted of mail or wire fraud. Restitution is required for victims directly harmed by the defendant's crime, while property proceeds from fraud can be confiscated by the United States through civil or criminal forfeiture procedures. The forfeiture of property can occur through civil or criminal procedures, with civil proceedings treating the property as the defendant and criminal proceedings being part of the prosecution of the property owner. Mail and wire fraud statutes prohibit dishonesty and may overlap with other federal criminal statutes, such as crimes where mail or wire fraud are elements, fraud under different circumstances, and honest services fraud like bribery. Some federal offenses require the commission of another federal offense, like money laundering outlawing the proceeds of predicate crimes. The Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) provisions outlaw acquiring or conducting the affairs of an enterprise through a pattern of racketeering activity that impacts interstate commerce. The elements of the RICO conduct offense include conducting the affairs of an enterprise engaged in activities that impact interstate commerce through a pattern of racketeering activity. The RICO provisions prohibit conducting the affairs of an enterprise through a pattern of racketeering activity that affects interstate commerce. A RICO pattern requires at least two acts of racketeering activity that are related and amount to continued criminal activity. Liability under RICO is not limited to upper management but also includes lower-level participants in the enterprise. The RICO provisions prohibit conducting the affairs of an enterprise through a pattern of racketeering activity that affects interstate commerce. Liability under RICO is not limited to upper management but also includes lower-level participants in the enterprise. An association-in-fact enterprise must have at least three structural features: a purpose, relationships among those associated with the enterprise, and longevity. Qualified enterprises are those engaged in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce. Penalties for violations include imprisonment for up to 20 years and fines up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). Money laundering includes mail and wire fraud as predicate offenses under RICO. Money laundering involves engaging in financial transactions with proceeds from illegal activities to conceal their source or promote further crimes. To prove this offense, the government must show that the defendant knowingly conducted a transaction affecting interstate or foreign commerce with illegal proceeds, knowing they were from unlawful activity, and with the intention to conceal their nature or ownership. To prove money laundering, the government must show that the defendant conducted a financial transaction involving proceeds of unlawful activity with the intent to promote or conceal. Merely depositing proceeds is not enough without proof of intent. Violation of Section 1956 requires intent to promote or conceal, with penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment and a $500,000 fine. Violation of Section 1957 involves transactions over $10,000. Section 1957 of 18 U.S.C. requires transactions involving over $10,000 and uses Section 1956's definition of unlawful activities. Unlike Section 1956, it does not require knowledge of intent to conceal. Penalties include imprisonment up to 10 years and fines up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). Offenses under this category involve fraud against the United States or share elements with mail and wire fraud. The proscriptions against defrauding the United States include submission of false claims, conspiracy to defraud, and material false statements. Section 287 outlaws the knowing submission of a false claim against the United States, with penalties of imprisonment for up to five years and fines up to $250,000. The general conspiracy statute prohibits conspiracies to violate US laws and conspiracies to defraud the US. To convict under the 'defraud' clause, the government must show an agreement to obstruct a lawful government function through deceitful means. The fraud covered by the statute includes impairing government functions through deceit or dishonesty. Unlike mail and wire fraud, the scheme does not have to aim to deprive another of money or property. The general conspiracy statute prohibits conspiracies to violate US laws and conspiracies to defraud the US by obstructing governmental functions through deceitful means. Penalties for such schemes include imprisonment for up to five years and fines up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). Section 1001 outlaws making material false statements within federal jurisdiction, with penalties for knowingly and willfully doing so. Local government agencies receiving federal support or subject to federal regulation may face penalties of imprisonment for up to five years and a fine of up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). Chapter 63 also includes other fraud proscriptions such as bank fraud, health care fraud, securities and commodities fraud, and fraud in foreign labor contracting, each with its own jurisdictional base. The bank fraud statute prohibits schemes to defraud federally insured financial institutions or falsely obtain property from them. To establish the offense, the government must prove the defendant knowingly executed a scheme to defraud a financial institution with the intent to do so. The health care fraud provision in Chapter 63 condemns schemes to defraud, including honest services fraud like bribery and kickbacks. Attempts and conspiracies to violate its prohibitions carry the same penalties as the complete offense. It is often prosecuted alongside other related offenses. Penalties include imprisonment for up to 30 years and a fine of up to $1 million. The health care fraud provision in Chapter 63 condemns schemes to defraud health care benefit programs. Penalties include fines up to $250,000 for individuals and $500,000 for organizations, along with imprisonment for various durations depending on the outcome of the fraud. Section 1348 addresses securities and commodities fraud with severe penalties for offenders. Section 1348 prohibits securities and commodities fraud with elements including fraudulent intent, a scheme to defraud, and a nexus with a security. Violation requires executing a scheme with fraudulent intent to obtain money or property through false pretenses. Penalties include up to 25 years imprisonment and fines up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). Fraud in foreign labor contracting under 18 U.S.C. § 1351 involves recruiting or hiring individuals outside the U.S. with penalties for offenders. The offense of fraud in foreign labor contracting under 18 U.S.C. § 1351 involves using false pretenses to secure employment for individuals outside the United States. Penalties include imprisonment for up to five years and fines of up to $250,000 ($500,000 for organizations). Additionally, bribery and kickback schemes are covered under various statutes such as 18 U.S.C. §§ 201(b)(1), 666, and 1951, as well as 15 U.S.C. §§ 78dd-1 to 78dd-3. Conviction for bribery of federal officials under Section 201(b)(1) requires proof of offering something of value to influence an official act. The offense involves a corrupt quid pro quo with the intent to give or receive something in exchange for an official act. Public officials covered include federal officers, employees, and those working for the United States or its agencies. The corrupt bargain involves official acts related to matters before an individual in his official capacity, with penalties including imprisonment for up to 15 years and fines up to $250,000. Section 666 prohibits fraud and bribery by agents of entities receiving over $10,000 in federal benefits in transactions of $5,000 or more. Proof of five elements is required for a violation, including being an agent of an organization receiving federal benefits, obtaining property through fraud, and having control over the organization's property. "A person is guilty under § 666[(a)(1)(B)] if, as an agent of an organization receiving federal funds, they solicit or accept anything of value intending to be influenced in transactions involving property worth $5,000 or more. Penalties include imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines up to $250,000. The Hobbs Act prohibits obtaining property under 'color of official right' affecting interstate commerce." Conviction under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act requires the government to prove that a government official accepted property not entitled to, knowing it was in exchange for official acts with an effect on commerce. Penalties include imprisonment up to 20 years and fines up to $250,000. The Act prohibits bribery by issuers, domestic concerns, and foreign trade practices. The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act prohibits bribery by issuers, domestic concerns, and others within the United States. It criminalizes corrupt practices involving foreign officials to influence their decisions or secure improper advantages. Penalties include imprisonment up to 20 years and fines up to $250,000. The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act prohibits bribery involving foreign officials to influence decisions or gain improper advantages. Penalties include imprisonment up to 20 years and fines up to $250,000. The Act also prohibits payments to expedite routine governmental actions, with penalties of imprisonment up to five years and fines up to $100,000 ($2 million for organizations). The Medicare/Medicaid kickback prohibition outlaws offering or receiving remuneration to induce referrals or purchases for Medicare/Medicaid beneficiaries, with penalties of imprisonment up to five years and fines up to $25,000.
